data.text: The IMF has taken decisive action to help countries, large and small, fight the #COVID19 economic crisis with the creation of a new Short-term Liquidity Line. This facility further strengthens the global financial safety net to tackle the crisis. https://t.co/nRW9GROIwQ #IMFBlog

Don’t miss @KGeorgieva’s conversation with @AtlanticCouncil @FredKempe on the economic consecuences of COVID-19, and the steps for the global economy to survive and emerge from the current crisis. #ACfrontpage

TOMORROW at 10:30am EST: https://t.co/XJWj8AdxAi https://t.co/dCchMrKmMJ
Extending an economic lifeline: governments are doing whatever it takes to help small firms survive the economic crisis brought on by #COVID19: https://t.co/KXDk1hcrYG
Which countries have received IMF emergency financial assistance to face the economic impact of #COVID19 so far? See the updated list here: https://t.co/lJlAHDqkKl https://t.co/esBqBMLztj

While the economy is shut down, policymakers need to ensure that people are able to meet their needs & businesses can pick up once the worst of the pandemic pass. This will require substantial targeted fiscal, monetary, and financial measures. https://t.co/93xXDRsg3B https://t.co/Dk3wYxbERY

When global capital pipelines freeze, a short-term liquidity problem can become a deeper, longer-lasting solvency problem. A liquidity line then can be a lifeline. The IMF has responded with a new facility:the Short-term Liquidity Line. #IMFBlog https://t.co/nRW9GRx7Fi https://t.co/Gjk66p5BVV

The global economy is expected to contract sharply to -3% in 2020 with a partial rebound to 5.8% in 2021 provided economic activity normalizes. However, uncertainty is exceptionally high. See projections by region in the latest #WEO #IMFBlog https://t.co/93xXDRsg3B https://t.co/AcGjTMhxs2

.@KGeorgieva asks epidemiologists @azraghani and @neil_ferguson of @imperialcollege what economists should be considering as the #COVID19 pandemic runs its course. Listen to the @imf_podcast https://t.co/yDJFHUChUD https://t.co/7YZJ47riOd

With the peak of the outbreak still ahead, many poor countries will need significant support to tackle the health crisis & minimize bankruptcies & job losses, while facing mounting external financing needs. The IMF is stepping up to help: https://t.co/Uh0vYbhzO7 #IMFBlog #COVID19 https://t.co/jhPloWFS3N

Small and medium-size firms are at greater risk as they struggle to repay loans and pay workers. But there are some innovative ways governments can help them. #COVID19 #IMFBlog https://t.co/KXDk1hcrYG https://t.co/dqwOshQEz1

#Samoa suffered from a severe measles outbreak in late-2019. #COVID19 has further exacerbated the economic downturn. Today, the IMF approved over US$22 million of emergency financing for Samoa to better cope with the economic impact of the pandemic.
https://t.co/fPhAxFKEkT https://t.co/VpHr1IpFVv

The IMF has taken decisive action to help countries, large and small, fight the #COVID19 economic crisis with the creation of a new Short-term Liquidity Line. .@KGeorgieva and @WTODGAZEVEDO highlight the role of open trade policies in defeating #COVID19, restoring jobs, and reinvigorating economic growth. Open trade in critical medical supplies and food translate into saving lives and livelihoods. Read statement https://t.co/4gBRCWE7oW https://t.co/mGESbgkniG

The April 2020 World Economic Outlook projects the global economy will contract sharply by -3% in 2020 as a result of the #COVID19 pandemic, a much worse contraction than during the 2008–09 financial crisis. Read the #WEO report https://t.co/93xXDRsg3B
The US has introduced some innovative ways to help support distressed companies during the crisis. Other countries can borrow a page from this playbook. #IMFBlog #COVID19 https://t.co/KXDk1hu2Qe

The IMF Executive Board approved US$130 million in emergency financing to help #Mauritania address the #COVID19 crisis by:
•Increasing spending on health services
•Strengthening social protection programs 
•Catalyzing additional donor support

When global capital pipelines freeze, a short-term liquidity problem can become a deeper, longer-lasting solvency problem. A liquidity line then can be a lifeline.The IMF has responded with a new facility:the Short-term Liquidity Line. @gwsokamoto #IMFBlog https://t.co/nRW9GRx7Fi https://t.co/qqjNP1YP08

A new IMF lending facility, the Short-term Liquidity Line, provides a reliable and renewable credit line, without conditions upon drawing, to members with very strong fundamentals and policy frameworks. #IMFBlog #COVID19 https://t.co/nRW9GRx7Fi https://t.co/iU7E1IjuMF

.@KGeorgieva & the RFAs remain committed to working together to coordinate assistance across the world. Where appropriate & feasible, they will cooperate to facilitate co-financing operations to address members’ needs & stand ready to provide technical assistance & policy advice.

During a conference call w/ heads of the world’s Regional Financing Arrangements, IMF Chief @KGeorgieva & the group emphasized their readiness to cooperate to mitigate the impact of the #COVID19 pandemic on the global economy & contribute to its recovery. https://t.co/jMAlpK8nhB https://t.co/hM4CEEpkSi

The contraction in advanced economies—where several countries are experiencing widespread outbreaks and deploying containment measures—is projected at -6.1% in 2020. Most economies in the group are in recession this year. Read more in the #WEO https://t.co/93xXDRsg3B https://t.co/5ZvYCxHZeO

Global growth is expected to contract by -3% in 2020. Assuming the pandemic fades in the second half of 2020 & that policy actions taken by countries are effective, global growth can be expected to partially rebound to 5.8 % in 2021. @GitaGopinath on #WEO https://t.co/93xXDRsg3B https://t.co/vw7gITLkfI

Sub-Saharan #Africa’s economy is set to shrink by a record 1.6% this year—the lowest since at least 1970, with real per capita income falling by 3.9%. https://t.co/S4tJuc6LyT #IMFAfrica #COVID19 https://t.co/Lyr9XTL6Z0

Since the Great Depression, this is the first time both advanced economies and emerging market and developing economies are in recession: growth in AEs is projected at -6.1% and EMDEs -1.0%.
